snippet.textDisplay:
@KTBMedia
It's an interesting question, for many the answer will simply be this game, Silent Hill 2. It doesn't rely on cheap spooks (although there are one or two in there, of course), instead it focuses on creating a bleak setting and examining the character's psyche, on a much deeper level than may be apparent initially. 3 also achieves a similar effect with a story coming from a very, very different angle to that of James', but playing the first game (which, again, comes from a very different tone to 2) is essential before playing 3 as it is a direct continuation, where 2 can stand perfectly on it's own.

If you thik you'd enjoy old school point and click games, I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream is a very psychological experience. The "gameplay" is pretty much what you'd expect from such a game, but the story and exploration of it's characters stand out way beyond a regular old game of it's style. I don't find it grabs me in a normal "horror" way, but it definately sticks with you.

There are other great horror games that don't rely on psychological horror to achieve their spooks. For something more on atmosphere and the thrill of survival, the game that does that best for me is the remake of Resident Evil. Put it on a more challenging difficulty and it's a very tense experience. Plus it has a pretty interesting story if you pay attention all the information available to you.

And hey, if you still want to play something hide and seek style (kinda like these modern jump scare only games, only better) take a look at Siren + Blood Curse which nail the atmosphere.
snippet.textOriginal:
@KTBMedia
It's an interesting question, for many the answer will simply be this game, Silent Hill 2. It doesn't rely on cheap spooks (although there are one or two in there, of course), instead it focuses on creating a bleak setting and examining the character's psyche, on a much deeper level than may be apparent initially. 3 also achieves a similar effect with a story coming from a very, very different angle to that of James', but playing the first game (which, again, comes from a very different tone to 2) is essential before playing 3 as it is a direct continuation, where 2 can stand perfectly on it's own.

If you thik you'd enjoy old school point and click games, I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream is a very psychological experience. The "gameplay" is pretty much what you'd expect from such a game, but the story and exploration of it's characters stand out way beyond a regular old game of it's style. I don't find it grabs me in a normal "horror" way, but it definately sticks with you.

There are other great horror games that don't rely on psychological horror to achieve their spooks. For something more on atmosphere and the thrill of survival, the game that does that best for me is the remake of Resident Evil. Put it on a more challenging difficulty and it's a very tense experience. Plus it has a pretty interesting story if you pay attention all the information available to you.

And hey, if you still want to play something hide and seek style (kinda like these modern jump scare only games, only better) take a look at Siren + Blood Curse which nail the atmosphere.

snippet.textDisplay:
Great song but why is it called Laura's theme? 
I mean it's the main theme of the game, uses the same melody as SH1 theme, and represents Silent Hill as a whole. Also during the video it shows pretty much his quest to find his wife (with bits of other parts).

So why is named after Laura and not Mary's theme?
snippet.textOriginal:
Great song but why is it called Laura's theme? 
I mean it's the main theme of the game, uses the same melody as SH1 theme, and represents Silent Hill as a whole. Also during the video it shows pretty much his quest to find his wife (with bits of other parts).

So why is named after Laura and not Mary's theme?

snippet.textDisplay:
Silent Hill is my favourite video game series that I've never played. I've watched most of the games played on YouTube and read into them, but short of a small amount of Homecoming I've yet to really experience Silent Hill first hand. 

But I have ordered the HD collection (2 & 3) so that should be fun if it doesn't scare the shit out of me.
snippet.textOriginal:
Silent Hill is my favourite video game series that I've never played. I've watched most of the games played on YouTube and read into them, but short of a small amount of Homecoming I've yet to really experience Silent Hill first hand. 

But I have ordered the HD collection (2 & 3) so that should be fun if it doesn't scare the shit out of me.

snippet.textDisplay: Hey everybody - I just released my solo album "Mirror Image" that contains ambient songs (and upbeat songs) heavily inspired by the world of Silent Hill and music of Akira Yamaoka. If you're interested you can check out the songs on my youtube page, and links to my myspace page and places to download the full album are on my youtube channel as well :) . Safe travels, keep your flashlight on and your radio close...
snippet.textOriginal: Hey everybody - I just released my solo album "Mirror Image" that contains ambient songs (and upbeat songs) heavily inspired by the world of Silent Hill and music of Akira Yamaoka. If you're interested you can check out the songs on my youtube page, and links to my myspace page and places to download the full album are on my youtube channel as well :) . Safe travels, keep your flashlight on and your radio close...

snippet.textDisplay: @Akujitsu That's because movies now are all about money, where it is almost impossible for any form of an indie project to break through. As its so money driven any real innovation is killed off. I don't think gaming has quite gone that way yet, and am currently enjoying modern gaming, albeit i still constantly reminisce on what it used to be like. So i definitely agree that gmaes have overtaken film as an artform.
snippet.textOriginal: @Akujitsu That's because movies now are all about money, where it is almost impossible for any form of an indie project to break through. As its so money driven any real innovation is killed off. I don't think gaming has quite gone that way yet, and am currently enjoying modern gaming, albeit i still constantly reminisce on what it used to be like. So i definitely agree that gmaes have overtaken film as an artform.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Akujitsu  but that's almost worse.  Dragoon's soundtrack is depressingly mediocre.  It's battle music is awful, along with it's unfitting "alternate" battle music that sounds like elevator music.  And the rest of the soundtrack isn't much better.

At least put Ocarina of Time, Super Metroid, and Secret of mana on such a list before you put Dragoon...
snippet.textOriginal:
@Akujitsu  but that's almost worse.  Dragoon's soundtrack is depressingly mediocre.  It's battle music is awful, along with it's unfitting "alternate" battle music that sounds like elevator music.  And the rest of the soundtrack isn't much better.

At least put Ocarina of Time, Super Metroid, and Secret of mana on such a list before you put Dragoon...

snippet.textDisplay: Someday there will be no such thing as movies. Hollywood will cry out for video game designers and actors to play in them. Who wants to watch a movie when they can live one. I see this happening many years from now but it will happen.

If I could use two words to describe what silent hill is about they would be guilt and sorrow.

If I only get one word it would be sorrow. Endless endless sorrow.

snippet.textDisplay: My favorite song out of all the Silent Hill games. Akira Yamaoko is easily one of the truly great video game composers. His work on Silent Hill is on par with what Nobuo Uematsu has done for Final Fantasy.
snippet.textOriginal: My favorite song out of all the Silent Hill games. Akira Yamaoko is easily one of the truly great video game composers. His work on Silent Hill is on par with what Nobuo Uematsu has done for Final Fantasy.

snippet.textDisplay:
I recommend this game to anyone who is more interested in a story than any other aspect of the game.

It has way too much symbolism though, which is why I love it.

snippet.textDisplay:
If this isn't your FAVORITE Silent Hill song, you have no taste. It better be at least in the top 3.

To me, this is MY FAVORITE VG song. There are SO many emotions in the song itself. Its as deep as Silent Hill 2. Slow tune, starts upbeat, goes dark, then goes more like, soothing yet creepy...It just is all over the place and I can't get enough of it.
snippet.textOriginal:
If this isn't your FAVORITE Silent Hill song, you have no taste. It better be at least in the top 3.

To me, this is MY FAVORITE VG song. There are SO many emotions in the song itself. Its as deep as Silent Hill 2. Slow tune, starts upbeat, goes dark, then goes more like, soothing yet creepy...It just is all over the place and I can't get enough of it.
